description: From Middle English guschen, gusshen, gosshien, perhaps from Middle Dutch guysen (“to flow out with a gurgling sound, gush”) or Old Norse gusa (“to gush”), ultimately imitative.
Compare Old Norse geysa (“to gush”), German gießen (“to pour”), Old English ġēotan ("to pour"; > English yote). Related to gust.

examples: There was a cartoon woman in an apron on the front. She stood with one hand on her hip while she used the other hand to pour a gush of drain-cleaner into something that was either an industrial sink or Orson Welles's bidet.

verbs.description: gush (third-person singular simple present gushes, present participle gushing, simple past and past participle gushed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, also figurative) To flow forth suddenly, in great volume.
examples: Water gushed out of the broken pipe.
After he was stabbed, blood came gushing out his throat.

entries.meaning: (transitive, also figurative) To send (something) flowing forth suddenly in great volume.
(intransitive, especially of a woman) To ejaculate during orgasm.
(intransitive, transitive, figurative) To make an excessive display of enthusiasm, praise, or sentiment.
examples: All the complaints she'd bottled up came gushing out during their marriage counselling session.
